unnormalised: Okay, so someone asked about donating to charity in India, right? Let's talk ₹₹. You see those donation boxes at temples? Some are legit, some…not so much. Always do your research before giving anything, especially cash.
normalised: Okay, so someone asked about donating to charity in India, right? Let's talk rupees. You see those donation boxes at temples? Some are legit, some…not so much. Always do your research before giving anything, especially cash.

unnormalised: Now, if you're looking for tax deductions, that's a different ballgame. Donations to registered trusts and organizations under Section 80G of the Income Tax Act can get you some relief. But you gotta have the receipt, okay? And the registration number. No number, no tax benefit. Simple as that.
normalised: Now, if you're looking for tax deductions, that's a different ballgame. Donations to registered trusts and organizations under Section eighty G of the Income Tax Act can get you some relief. But you gotta have the receipt, okay? And the registration number. No number, no tax benefit. Simple as that.

unnormalised: There are tons of organizations out there. CRY (Child Rights and You), Goonj, Helpage India…the list is endless. Do some digging, find one whose work really resonates with you. Don’t just blindly give 'cause someone on WhatsApp forwarded a message.
normalised: There are tons of organizations out there. C-R-Y (Child Rights and You), Goonj, Helpage India…the list is endless. Do some digging, find one whose work really resonates with you. Don’t just blindly give 'cause someone on WhatsApp forwarded a message.

unnormalised: Also, think beyond just money. Maybe you have old clothes you don’t wear anymore? Goonj is great for that. Or maybe you can volunteer your time? A lot of NGOs are always looking for helping hands. Especially around Diwali time, they need all the help they can get.
normalised: Also, think beyond just money. Maybe you have old clothes you don’t wear anymore? Goonj is great for that. Or maybe you can volunteer your time? A lot of N-G-Os are always looking for helping hands. Especially around Diwali time, they need all the help they can get.

unnormalised: Speaking of money, it’s not always about donating huge amounts. Even a small amount can make a difference. Rs. 100, Rs. 500…every bit counts. Think of it as skipping your daily chai for a week and donating that money. Small sacrifice, big impact.
normalised: Speaking of money, it’s not always about donating huge amounts. Even a small amount can make a difference. Rupees one hundred, Rupees five hundred…every bit counts. Think of it as skipping your daily chai for a week and donating that money. Small sacrifice, big impact.

unnormalised: Now, I know a lot of people are wary of giving money because they don't know where it goes. That’s a valid concern. Look for organizations that are transparent about their finances. They should have their annual reports available online. See how much goes to actual programs versus administrative costs.
normalised: Now, I know a lot of people are wary of giving money because they don't know where it goes. That’s a valid concern. Look for organizations that are transparent about their finances. They should have their annual reports available online. See how much goes to actual programs versus administrative costs.

unnormalised: Finally, remember why you're donating. It's not just about tax benefits or feeling good about yourself. It's about helping people in need. It's about making a small dent in the problem of poverty and inequality. And that’s worth way more than any amount of money, bhai. So, find a cause you believe in, do your homework, and give generously (but smartly!). Even if it's just ₹200 a month. Every little bit helps.
